meeting_annotations.speaker: Betar Gallant (MIT)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um one one reflection I've had um I guess while we're on the topic of integration of uh our multifunctional processes is um you know I think it can open many doors and the science can be quite beautiful and at the same time we create new constraints on processes um when we try to make things you know do multiple have multiple functionalities and like um many years ago I was sort of immersed in the you know like photo electrochemical conversion of CO2 and that was always I don't work in that now but it was always an interesting problem um because there's opportunities but also when you constrain material to be a you know light absorber and have to integrate catalyst and do many things then you also have a narrower I mean by some arguments could have a narrower uh parameter space and I think you know one of the beautiful things about um sorbents and things that kind of already have affinities for CO2 is they can create really neat new mechanisms and then one of the challenges is they're not at all designed to be like friendly with if it's an electrochemical process just to keep with the example. You know they're they're bulky they have steric issues they don't want to you know so I think um they can thwart your ionic conductivity or sometimes they do become ionic conductors and so I've been thinking a lot about how you kind of you kind of have to have your eye on both um on that challenge in the beginning because you can inadvertently make a very complex system and then and then you have to figure out maybe why it doesn't work can take quite some time.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Marcel Schreier - UW-Sc Madison
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I I think this is a very nice point and I share your experience. I started with photo electrochemical CO2 reduction and after about two years I was like I'm not integrating everything on one thing and I took it apart. Maybe you know the literature. Um but so what I want to ask here is about this integration. Uh so I want to build on on Betar's argument because integration has pros and cons and I would really like to hear what people think. So the pros of integrating is if you integrate um capture and conversion, you can make products that potentially can be transported better, more easily. Um CO2 is a gas, ideally we could make a liquid, it would be easier to kind of gather together and and transport to a point of use. On on the other hand, um if we integrate capture and conversion, capture is not the very high intensity process. The CO2 is at 400 ppm, we need to pump immense amounts of air through the absorbers to get meaningful mole molar quantities of carbon dioxide. And then if we want to do conversion at the same site, my concern is that we will under utilize, for example, the catalytic or chemic or electro catalytic conversion system because we end up having the need of of transporting electrons through very large surface areas if we want to do the conversion directly on the absorbent, right? Which is really massive when you look at the systems built by Climeworks. And um so it it comes kind of down again to the same question like isn't it from an engineering point of view more reasonable to intensify the conversion process to essentially concentrate the CO2 up and then separately kind of do the conversion in a more intensified process than the capture. And I I would really like to hear the thoughts of people about this.
